review.title: Finding Coordinated Paths for Multiple Holonomic Agents in 2-d Polygonal Environment
review.abstract: Avoiding collisions is one of the vital tasks for systems of autonomous mobile agents. We focus on the problem of finding continuous coordinated paths for multiple mobile disc agents in a 2-d environment with polygonal obstacles. The problem is PSPACE-hard, with the state space growing exponentially in the number of agents. Therefore, the state of the art methods include mainly reactive techniques and sampling-based iterative algorithms.
histories: Proceedings of the 13th International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS 2014)
review.COMMENTS: Proceedings of the 13th International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS 2014)

metadata.title: Finding Coordinated Paths for Multiple Holonomic Agents in 2-d Polygonal Environment

sections.text: We compare the performance of a widely used reactive method ORCA with three variants of a popular planning algorithm RRT *, which is applied to multi-agent planning, and find that an algorithm that combines reactive collision avoidance and RRT * planning, which we call ORCA-RRT *, can be used to solve cases that are often beyond the reach of either technique. We demonstrate experimentally that: 1) the reactive part of the algorithm can efficiently solve many problems in the search for multiagents involving a large number of agents, for which the RRT * algorithm often cannot find a solution in a limited time, and 2) the planning component of the algorithm is capable of solving many cases with local minima, where reactive techniques typically fail. Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.11 [ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE]: Distributed Artificial Intelligence Intelligent Keywords Intelligent Performance, Multiactive Problem Solving; General Problem Solutions;

sections.heading: 2. PROBLEM STATEMENT
sections.text: Consider n agents operating in two-dimensional euclidean space with polygonal obstacles; the starting positions of the agents are given as n-tuple (s1,..., sn), where si is the starting position of the i-agent; the n-tuple (d1,..., dn) indicates the destinations of the agents; we assume that the agents have disk-shaped bodies in which the radius of the agent i is designated ri; the final orbit of the i-agent πi (t) is an illustration R → R2 of the time t to the two-dimensional euclidean space of the agent in which πi (0) = si; the time t d i is the minimum time after which the i-agent remains at the destination, tdi = min (ti | t) < ti (t) = di.

sections.heading: 3.1 Multi-agent Extensions
sections.text: The key component that influences the performance of the RRT algorithm is the local steering method, in which only three real collisions are generated. We consider a multi-agent steering function in the following form: 1 Here, we assume that the xgoal point is sampled with a certain non-zero probability (e.g. 1%) to overcome the need to define the target as a region rather than a point.

sections.heading: 4. EXPERIMENTAL ANALYSIS
sections.text: In this section we evaluate experimentally the characteristics of the proposed extension of the multi-agent RRT * algorithm. We compare three RRT * -based algorithms - line RRT *, visibility diagram RRT * and ORCA RRT * with reactive ORCA. Experiments were performed on four types of 2d test environments - empty, door, cross and labyrinth environments (see Figure 2). All environments are limited by a fixed limit of 1000x1000. Comparative measures focus on the success rate of the algorithms and the quality of the solution for different environmental conditions. The measured parameters are: • Idealistic solution costs are the costs of a solution for which the CF function in Equation 1 is loosened in such a way that it disregards its first limitation, i.e. allows collisions between the agents. The idealistic (i.e. lower bound) solution costs is astideal = n = 1di.

sections.heading: 4.1 Benchmark set
sections.text: The experiment was carried out using a benchmark set consisting of four environments as shown in Figure 2, with the number of agents varying from 2 to 10 and the body radii of the agents varying from 50 to 100. For each combination of environment, number of agents and agent radius, the benchmark set contains 10 different settings of the starting and destination positions of the agents, totaling 2160 benchmark scenarios. Since RRT * is a stochastic algorithm, we run the algorithm five times with different random seeds for each problem instance. Overall, the presented experimental results are based on 34560 rounds. The benchmark set was created by an algorithm that guarantees that there is exactly one collision cluster for each problem instance, i.e. the path-finding problem cannot be divided into non-colliding groups of agents, which would be easier to solve. This is guaranteed by adding the random start and target positions of the agent, i.e. the path-finding problem can only be divided between each agent and the other, if a shortest path and each agent occurs.

sections.heading: 4.2 Success rate
sections.text: It is the time when all solutions above 5 are considered unsuccessful. In Figure 6, we consider all solutions above 2.5 to be unsuccessful. We can observe three significant phenomena.

sections.heading: 4.3 Suboptimality
sections.text: Figure 7 and 8 shows the histograms of the ranks assigned to the run-time limitation algorithms of 5 and 1 seconds. Each algorithm is assigned a rank of 1 to 4 for each experiment according to its solution suboptimality compared to other algorithms. If two algorithms achieve the same sub-optimality, the ranks are assigned to them randomly. If an algorithm could not find a solution, its rank is 4th. We observe that the VisibilityGraph-RRT * algorithm has reached the lowest substance optimality for a given problem substance. Line-RRT * is slightly better due to its ability to scan the state space very quickly. ORCA algorithm reached the second rank and ORCA-RRT * always reached the first place in the majority of the problem ranges, while the difference between the 7 and the ARCA shows the best solution * the difference in the problem ranges.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we investigated the problem of finding coordinated pathways for holonomic agents in two-dimensional polygonal environments, a problem that is challenging due to its prohibitive complexity. We examined several RRT * -based algorithms for multi-agent coordinated pathfinding and a reactive approach to ORCA. We found that while both approaches have limited coverage of the problematic instance space, an approach that combines planning and reactive technology benefits both parts, thereby providing better coverage of the problem instance and higher quality of solvement.We call the new algorithm ORCA-RRT *. While RRT * -based algorithms often suffer from the exponential growth of government space and are therefore unable to solve cases with a high number of agents, the reactive part of ORCA-RRT * is able to solve this problem. On the other hand, reactive techniques are often unable to solve problems that contain minima local ones.

referenceMentions.context: In theory it is well known that finding even non-optimal collision-free paths from defined start positions to goal positions for a group of objects in restricted 2-d space is PSPACE-hard [3] and thus (unless P=PSPACE) there exist instances that cannot be solved in polynomial time.

For this variant of the problem there exist complete polynomial algorithms such as BIBOX [7] or Push & Rotate [1], nonpolynomial (but often effective) optimal algorithms [6] and anytime algorithms [9].

For this variant of the problem there exist complete polynomial algorithms such as BIBOX [7] or Push & Rotate [1], nonpolynomial (but often effective) optimal algorithms [6] and anytime algorithms [9].

Frequently used decoupled technique is prioritized planning [2].
In 2011 Karaman and Frazzoli [4] published the RRT* ar X iv :1 40 2.
algorithm, an anytime extension of RRT (rapidly exploring random tree [5]) that is probabilistically complete and asymptotically optimal.
[8] and demonstrated to be capable of generating collision-free motion for a large number of agents in a cluttered workspace with local guarantees on optimality and safety.
The algorithm searches for a path p : [0, 1]→ J from xinit to xgoal, which can be then decomposed into a set trajectories {πi} for each individual agent i.

1 Line Extension The first considered extension method is a relatively straightforward extension of classical single-agent RRT* planner as exposed in [4], which connects two states using straight line paths.

Given the agent’s desired velocity and the constraints induced by the other agents, a linear program with n − 1 constraints is constructed and solved to obtain the optimal velocity vector the agent should follow in the next time step [8].
Note that RRT* is provably probabilistically complete [4], but for some instances given the limited runtime the algorithm was not able to find even the first feasible solution.

metadata.abstractText: Avoiding collisions is one of the vital tasks for systems of autonomous mobile agents. We focus on the problem of finding continuous coordinated paths for multiple mobile disc agents in a 2-d environment with polygonal obstacles. The problem is PSPACE-hard, with the state space growing exponentially in the number of agents. Therefore, the state of the art methods include mainly reactive techniques and sampling-based iterative algorithms. We compare the performance of a widely-used reactive method ORCA with three variants of a popular planning algorithm RRT* applied to multi-agent path planning and find that an algorithm combining reactive collision avoidance and RRT* planning, which we call ORCA-RRT* can be used to solve instances that are out of the reach of either of the techniques. We experimentally show that: 1) the reactive part of the algorithm can efficiently solve many multi-agent path finding problems involving large number of agents, for which RRT* algorithm is often unable to find a solution in limited time and 2) the planning component of the algorithm is able to solve many instances containing local minima, where reactive techniques typically fail.
